description: The bat star is a starfish that comes in various colors (red, orange, yellow, brown, green, and purple) its webbing between its legs makes it look similar to a pentagon. It can grow up to eight inches or 20 cm across and commonly has five arms but can have up to nine arms. They use sensors at the end of their feet to “smell” their prey.

The Knobby Sea Star also known as the “jeweled star” is a small sea star that is covered with blue and white nubs. To eat it extends its stomach outside of its mouth and digests its prey outside of its body.

The Brittle Star is a unique-looking starfish with a pentagon disc with five long slender arms, on each arm are a row of spines. Are often found in middle or low intertidal pools. They can also live deep in the ocean on the sea floor. It is a suspension feeder meaning it raises its arms upward trapping plankton on its spines.

The Ochre Sea Star is a large orange or purple sea star with a rough bumpy texture. It is commonly known as a “keystone species” which indicates the health of an intertidal zone. Although they are slow they are avid hunters of small animals.

The Purple Sea Urchin looks like a donut without a hole with long purple-red spines extending outward from its core. They move with small tubular feet with suction cups to keep hold of surfaces. They eat algae, kelp, and dead matter.
The Red Sea Urchin looks like a 3d oval with long red spines pointing outward from its body.  They are found on hard surfaces and in rocky reefs. They can also live up to 100 years old.

Abalone is a marine snail, which is covered by a flattened spiral shell with a line of holes following one edge of its shell. They are commonly known for their beautiful iridescent shell and pearls which have been used for jewelry and art.

The California spiny lobster is found in the eastern Pacific Ocean ranging from Monterey Bay, California, to the Gulf of Tehuantepec, Mexico. It typically grows to a length of 12 inches (30 cm) and is reddish-brown with stripes along the legs. They have a pair of enlarged antennae but no claws. The interrupted grooves across the tail are characteristic for this species of spiny lobster. California spiny lobster females can carry up to 680,000 eggs!

The California Two-spot octopus can easily be found by the blue spots under its eyes. They usually live for one to two years and they can reach up to eight inches long. They enjoy eating clams and snails.

The California Sea Hare is a sea slug that can get huge and weigh up to 35 pounds! They come in various colors, usually shades of red and brown and they have antennas on the top of their head. They are herbivores who enjoy feeding on algae.

The Spanish Shawl is a super colorful sea slug. They have purple bodies and the cerata is orange. The cerata sticks up like a mohawk on its back. When being hunted by other predators they can move away by flexing their bodies and pushing off the water.

The Hopkins Rose is a pink sea slug known as a Nudibranch. They are carnivorous feeding on bottomfeeders and they have gills on the outside of their body. What’s interesting is that “Nudibranch” actually translates to naked gill!.

The red sponge dorid is a shell-less marine gastropod mollusk which is a species of sea slug. They are a dorid nudibranch which means they use gills, located on their back, to draw oxygen from the water.

The California Aglaja is a large sea slug that is covered in yellow streaks, and lines of blue dots. They feast on snails and small fish, and they use slime trails to ward off predators. They do not possess organs that allow them to see.

The Zebra Perch is a football-shaped fish with a spikey fin on top and a short tail. Its most notable feature and its namesake comes from its black and white vertical striping. They primarily eat red algae.

A football-shaped fish with a spikey dorsal fin, short tail, fins next to its head, another set of fins underneath its head, and fins near its rear. They are dullish green-gray and eat primarily algae.

The Giant Kelpfish is a long thin fish with two small long fins near its head, a short dorsal fin that extends the length of its body, and a bottom fin from mid-length to tail. The shape of their body helps them blend into the kelp. They can change their color to better match their surroundings.

The tidepool sculpin is a common fish found in tidepools in the intertidal zone of rocky coasts, swimming from one hiding place to another. Each time the tide recedes, they return back to the tidepool in which it has taken up residence. Their coloration is varied, but it is often marbled in grey, brown and white. However, they can quickly camouflage themselves by changing colors to match their surrounding habitat so you may find them in either reddish or greenish coloration. Tidepool sculpins are predators, feeding on small invertebrates such as isopods, amphipods, gastropod molluscs, polychaete worms and barnacles, as well as insects that happen to fall into the water. Small amounts of algae also form part of the diet.
